conclusion: To determine the direction of the acceleration during the 0 to 10 seconds interval, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The x-axis represents time t in seconds. The y-axis represents velocity v in meters per second (m/s).
We are focused on the time interval from t = 0 seconds to t = 10 seconds.
At t = 0 seconds, the velocity starts at 0 m/s. By t = 10 seconds, the velocity reaches approximately 20 m/s.

premise: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time (a = dv/dt). In the given graph, the velocity increases from 0 m/s to 20 m/s over the 10-second interval.
conclusion: Since the velocity is increasing, the acceleration must be positive.
The slope of the tangent line at any point on the velocity-time graph gives the instantaneous acceleration at that point.
Observing the tangent lines drawn on the graph between t = 0 seconds and t = 10 seconds, we see that the slope is consistently positive.

premise: The positive slope indicates that the acceleration is in the same direction as the velocity, which means it is directed downwards (since the skydiver is moving downwards).
conclusion: The direction of the acceleration during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is downwards.
